utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, you’re wrong. Wolverine was not born with bone claws.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard, you know me to be a very smart man. Don’t you think if I were wrong, I’d know it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, first of all…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Give it up, dude, you’re arguing with a crazy person.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not crazy. My mother had me tested.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, guys.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What do you mean? It’s new comic book night.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, but since you and Penny finally hooked up, we thought you two would be having bouncy naked yum-yum night.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There’s more to life than sex, Raj.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, who had Leonard flames out with Penny in less than 24 hours”?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I did.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nothing flamed out. We don’t have to have sex every night, you know.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You don’t have to, but it’s highly recommended.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, take advantage of that window of opportunity before it slams shut on your little dinky.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s not a matter of opportunity. We’re getting to know each other. There’s a learning curve.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What’s there to learn? You get naked, do nasty things to each other, then somebody makes scrambled eggs and salami. Easy peasy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Perhaps what Leonard is obliquely referring to is the occurrence of some sort of sexual dysfunction.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, who had Leonard gets a floppy disk?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, a clever, albeit obsolete, euphemism for insufficient blood flow to the male sex organ.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nothing like that happened, all right? The sex was just fine.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Just fine? Oh, dude, the fourth Harry Potter movie was just fine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not saying it was bad, I’m just saying it… wasn’t great.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, when you say “it wasn’t great, do you mean for both of you? Because we can totally see it not being great for her. Am I right?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: To tell you the truth, I think we were both a little, I don’t know…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Disappointed? Let down?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ashamed? Horrified? Repulsed?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: All I know is, it wasn’t the way I dreamed it would be.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sex is never the way I dream it’s gonna be.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That’s because in your dreams you’re a horse from the waist down.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me, Wolverine: Origin. Miniseries issue two, page 22. Retractable bone claws. If you people spent less time thinking about sex and more time concentrating on comic books, we’d have far fewer of these embarrassing moments.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, dinner’s here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Tandoori Palace?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, we went somewhere new.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re good-naturedly ribbing me, aren’t you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, look, Mumbai Palace.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why? Why would we change? We had a perfectly good palace. Tandoori Palace is our palace.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Trust me, this will be just fine.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You are the authority on just fine.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s that supposed to mean?

utterance.speaker: Howard (after Raj whispers to him)
utterance.content: Yeah, exactly. Not bad, but not great.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What are they talking about?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know. As I’m sure you’re aware…

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Duh-duh-duh-duh-duh-duh.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If that’s Morse code, that’s terrible. As I was saying, you and Leonard had a disappointing sexual encounter. Earlier this evening, Leonard characterized it as just fine. So what you’re seeing here is a continuation of the mocking that followed.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, yeah, well, I’m just gonna go eat my dinner elsewhere. Maybe an airplane headed for a mountainside.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny, wait. Aagh! What is wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I sense I may have crossed some sort of line.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, you…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Uh, no, no, no, don’t tell him, let’s see if he can figure it out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ugh, I am so embarrassed!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Please don’t be mad.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What did you tell them?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nothing bad, just that last night was fine.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Fine? You said it was fine?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s a perfectly good word. You put it in front of wine or dining, and you’ve really got something. Okay, well, let me ask you this, how was last night for you?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It was… okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s a perfectly good word. I mean, you put it in front of dokay and you really got something. All right, look, let’s not overreact, you know? For a lot of couples, it takes time to get to know each other’s rhythms. Learn what the other person wants and likes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, you’ve been through this before?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay-dokay.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, I think this is one of those things where talking about it is not going to make it better. Want a glass of wine?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So much.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. See, we should’ve done this last night, you know, have a little wine, take the edge off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Actually, ethyl alcohol inhibits electrical conduction in the nerve cells and stimulates reuptake receptors of inhibitory neurotransmitters like gamma-aminobutyric acid.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Don’t talk, just drink.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you’re misunderstanding. A shiksa goddess isn’t an actual goddess and we don’t pray to them, we prey on them.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Whatever, dude. The point is, Leonard’s got one and you don’t.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is this it? It was inappropriate to discuss Leonard and Penny’s sex life in front of Leonard and Penny. Oh, good! Now I can eat.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sounds like a cricket.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hang on. Based on the number of chirps per minute and the ambient temperature in this room, it is a snowy tree cricket.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, give me a frickin’ break. How could you possibly know that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In 1890, Emile Dolbear determined that there was a fixed relationship between the number of chirps per minute of the snowy tree cricket and the ambient temperature. A precise relationship that is not present with ordinary field crickets.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How do you know what the exact temperature of the room is?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Under the terms of my roommate agreement with Leonard, I’ve had unilateral control of the thermostat ever since the sweaty night of ’06.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, you were right about Wolverine and bone claws, but you’re wrong about the cricket.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard, don’t embarrass yourself, the science chirps for itself. Humorous word play.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, no, not this time. I know insects, my friend, I spent many childhood years capturing them with nets, putting them in glass jars, sticking pins through them, mounting them on corrugated cardboard with Dymo labels underneath, identifying the genus and species. In Latin.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, dude, you are never getting a shiksa goddess.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That is a snowy tree cricket. Oecanthus fultoni. I was done with Latin by fifth grade.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, okay, tell you what. I am willing to bet anything that’s an ordinary field cricket.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can’t take your money.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What’s the matter, you chicken?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve always found that an inappropriate slur. Chickens are not, by nature, at all timid. In fact, when I was young, my neighbour’s chicken got loose and chased me up the big elm tree in front of our house.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Chickens can’t climb trees

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank God.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I believe a chicken made you his bitch. But the cricket thing, I don’t buy. Bet me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fair enough. What stake do you propose?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I will put up my Fantastic Four number 48, first appearance of Silver Surfer against your Flash 123, the classic Flash of two worlds issue.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, you have a wager.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hmm.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Great. Now how are you going to settle it, hmm? There is no way to determine the species of the cricket without examining it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I wonder what the non-pathetic people are doing tonight.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: More wine?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hit me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Shh!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hallway.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: One at a time. What was that?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: My stomach. Indian food doesn’t agree with me. Ironic, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Shh! Elevator shaft.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Help me open it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Are you crazy? We can’t go down an empty elevator shaft.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine, if you don’t want to proceed, then you forfeit the bet, and I’ll take possession of your Fantastic Four.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Let’s open her up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you bothered that I can so easily manipulate you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t push me, Sheldon. I may be small, but I took kung fu when I was 13, and I remember a good deal of it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, really? Well, I grew up with an older brother and a very contentious twin sister and I believe I could easily best you in any physical confrontation, be it noogies, swirlies or the classic why are you hitting yourself?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ooh, big talk from a man who was once treed by a chicken.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are we drinking now?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Peppermint schnapps.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why would you buy peppermint schnapps?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Because I like peppermint, and it’s fun to say schnapps. Hey, Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Schnapps.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Schnapps. You’re right, that is fun.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Be careful.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If I were not being careful, your telling me to be careful would not make me careful.

utterance.speaker: Raj (hearing the cricket)
utterance.content: Stairwell.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uh-oh, flashlight went out. I need some batteries. Fellas? Hello? It’s really dark down here.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, sweetie. You really can’t hold your liquor, can you?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m okay. Just a little mouthwash, and then I’m gonna rock your world. Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ugh, Toby, what did you do in a past life to be so disgusting now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: His name isn’t Toby. Toby is an absurd name for a cricket.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What would you name him?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: An appropriate cricket name. For example, Jiminy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right, Sheldon, here we go, Kleingast’s Field Guide to North American Insects. Hey, Toby. Right here, see it? The common field cricket, aka Gryllus assimilis, which is Latin for suck it, you lose.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hang on. Voilà, the snowy tree cricket, aka Oecanthus fultoni, which is Latin for I’ll suck nothing. Of course I’m joking because the Latin for that is nihil exsorbibo.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That is not Toby, this is Toby. Raj, what do you think?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, I really don’t care anymore

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: God, I had the most horrible night.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Obviously another carnal fiasco with the shiksi goddess.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Shiksa. Shik-sa.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Forgive me. Yiddish was not spoken in east Texas. And if it was, it wasn’t spoken for long.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, fine, whatever. The point is, you’re wrong again.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We haven’t established that I’m wrong once.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right. Tell you what, let’s go down to the Entomology Department and let Professor

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He’s a snowy tree cricket, and his name is Jiminy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I bet I could throw a rock in this room and come up with three better friends.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Holy crap. It’s like Silence of the Lambs down here. Don’t do that!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’re such a girl. They’re just bugs.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, well, I don’t like bugs, okay? They freak me out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Interesting. You’re afraid of insects and women. Ladybugs must render you catatonic. It was a joke. I made it to lessen your discomfort. You’re welcome

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley (arriving)
utterance.content: Don’t knock. Just walk in. Why be polite to the world’s leading expert on the dung beetle?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me, are you Professor Crawley?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Who wants to know?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m Dr. Cooper from the Physics Department.

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Couldn’t wait, huh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: I haven’t even packed yet, and you’re already measuring my lab for one of your godless laser machines.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you don’t understand. We just want to ask you a question.

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Let me ask you one first. What’s a world renowned entomologist with a doctorate and 20 years of experience to do with his life when the university cuts off the funding for his lab, huh?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ask rhetorical questions that make people uncomfortable?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: What’s your deal? Are they planning to outsource my job to Bangalore?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m from New Delhi. Maybe you should find another entomologist.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no. We’re here, let’s settle this. Professor, can you identify our cricket?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Of course I can. I can identify every insect and arachnid on the planet. Not that that’s going to keep me from having to move in with my daughter in Oxnard. And we’re not talking Oxnard at the beach. No! We’re talking Oxnard in the onion fields.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, could you look at Toby?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Toby? What a stupid name for a cricket.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Told you.

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: It’s a field cricket.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, wait. Dr. Crawley, are you sure?

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Young man, I’ve been studying insects since I was eight years old. You know what they used to call me in school? Creepy Crawley.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Cruel as that may be, that is not in itself a credential.

utterance.speaker: Prof Crawley
utterance.content: Let me show you something. See that? That’s a Crawley’s dung beetle. I discovered it after spending six months slogging through a Bornean rain forest, while my wife was back home shacking up with a two-bit ornithologist who lives on a sailboat and likes to wear boot-cut jeans! So, when I tell you that that’s a common field cricket, you can take that to the damn bank! Cause God knows I can’t. That tramp took me for everything!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, apparently, I was wrong. Congratulations.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Enjoy Oxnard. I’m sure your daughter’s looking forward to having you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, hey, Sheldon. What you got there? A new comic book?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Old comic book. I just retrieved it from my safe deposit box.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What do you have a safe deposit box for?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Old comic books. I lost this to Wolowitz in an ill-considered cricket wager.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What, do they have Wii cricket now? That can’t be very popular.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, I’d rather not talk about it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, if it makes you feel any better, I’m not feeling so hot either.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why would that make me feel better?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know, empathy? Anyway, I’m just saying that you’re feeling upset about something with Howard, and I’m upset about something with Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, yes, the disappointing sex. That’s an inexact parallel. You and Leonard can always return to being friends, whereas I can never return to a state in which Wolowitz has not bested me like Mrs. Riley’s chicken.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What’s Mrs. Riley’s chicken?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A chicken that was owned by Mrs. Riley.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, forget the chicken.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I wish I could.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, no. You may be right about me and Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course I’m right What are the odds I’d be wrong twice in one week?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, I mean, we can always go back to being friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I just said that. This conversation has started to circle. Meeting adjourned.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, you’d like to catch up on the events of the day. All right. Well, there was a half-hour wait at the bank to get into my safe deposit box, I was forced to talk to Penny about your sexual problems, and, oh, yes, in a moment filled with biblical resonance, pride wenteth before my fall, causing my Flash 123 to goeth to Wolowitz.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wait a minute. You talked to Penny about our sex life?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, it astonishes me how you continually fixate on the trivial. I lost a bet to Wolowitz.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right, right. You’re saying you talked to Penny?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Interesting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hardly.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Excuse me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Have I crossed some sort of line again?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Little bit.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hmm. Oh, who cares?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, hey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey. Uh, what did Sheldon say to you?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Not a lot. Just that we always have the option of going back to being friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Is that what you want?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know. I mean, you have to admit things seemed simpler when we were just friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I guess.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It would take the pressure off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It would, wouldn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, we’ll just be friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good, good.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Come here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (closing door)
utterance.content: Okay-dokay
